Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Participate in community rituals and ceremonies
Situation2: A community memorial service at the temple takes place tonight with many attendees expected.
Story: I glance at my phone, rereading Mia’s message: “Let’s have a date night tonight? We finally have time!” My heart lifts. We’ve both been so busy, and I know how much she values these moments—just us, no distractions. I want to say yes immediately, to make her feel cherished. But then I remember the temple’s memorial service tonight. As a practicing Buddhist, I’m expected to attend, to support the community and honor those who’ve passed. The monks have mentioned how important it is for everyone to be present, especially for ceremonies like this. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in. Mia’s voice in my mind, hopeful and excited; the gentle, insistent call of the temple, reminding me of my commitment. I want to be the boyfriend who shows up, who makes her feel special. I want to be the Buddhist who honors tradition and community. My chest tightens as I stare at the calendar, torn between two promises, wishing I could be in both places at once.
